qas.question: Along with the National Museum of Nepal, what notable Nepalese museum is present in Kathmandu?
From what time period are the oldest artifacts in Kathmandu museums?
Along with Buddhism, what religion has had a significant influence on Nepal?
What Kathmandu valley area was named a World Heritage Site by UNESCO?
How many Monument Zones are present in the Kathmandu valley?

context: Kathmandu is home to a number of museums and art galleries, including the National Museum of Nepal and the <a0_0>Natural History Museum of Nepal<a0_0/>. Nepal's art and architecture is an amalgamation of two ancient religions, <a2_0>Hinduism<a2_0/> and Buddhhism. These are amply reflected in the many temples, shrines, stupas, monasteries, and palaces in the <a4_0>seven<a4_0/> well-defined <a3_0>Monument Zones<a3_0/> of the Kathmandu valley are part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This amalgamation is also reflected in the planning and exhibitions in museums and art galleries throughout Kathmandu and its sister cities of Patan and Bhaktapur. The museums display unique artifacts and paintings from the <a1_0>5th century<a1_0/> CE to the present day, including archeological exportation.
